title: 114_s2185
content:
The Act is titled the "Breast Cancer Awareness Commemorative Coin Act". Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women in the United States, with 1 in 8 women developing invasive breast cancer. It is the second leading cause of cancer death in women, but death rates have decreased since 1989 due to early detection and improved treatment. The National Cancer Institute estimates $18.1 billion was spent on breast cancer care in 2014. In 2014, $18.1 billion was spent on breast cancer care in the United States. The National Institutes of Health allocated $674 million for breast cancer research, while the Department of Defense's Breast Cancer Research Program received $120 million. Despite funding reductions for the National Cancer Institute, the Department of Defense's funding for breast cancer research has remained consistent since 2012. The Cancer Research Program funding has decreased by 20% from 2011 levels. Additional private sector support for breast cancer research is expected to accelerate finding cures. In the United States, an estimated 231,840 women will be diagnosed with breast cancer and 40,290 will die in 2015. African-American women have the highest death rates and are 44% more likely to die from breast cancer compared to other racial and ethnic groups. Breast cancer was previously considered a disease of aging. Breast cancer, once seen as a disease of aging, is now diagnosed more frequently in younger women. It is the most common cancer among various racial and ethnic groups. Research advancements have improved survival rates, with a 34% decrease in death rates since 1990. In 2015, an estimated 2,350 new cases of invasive breast cancer and 440 deaths among men were projected in the US. Breast cancer survivors in the US exceed 3.1 million. The estimated cost of breast cancer in lost productivity is $12.5 billion. Early detection through mammograms and exams improves survival chances. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women globally, with 1.7 million new cases in 2012. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation (BCRF) is a key organization in this field. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation (BCRF) is a highly efficient charity, with 91 cents of every dollar donated going towards research and awareness programs. Founded in 1993, BCRF has raised over $500 million for breast cancer research, making it one of the largest private funders in the world. In 2014 and 2015, BCRF committed $58.6 million to research, including funding for the international Evelyn H. Lauder Founder's Fund focused on metastasis. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender and considered numismatic items as per the specifications in title 31, United States Code. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of coins minted under this Act will symbolize the fight against breast cancer and include inscriptions of the face value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be chosen through a design competition organized by the Secretary. Compensation will be provided to the winner of the competition. The design competition for the coins minted under this Act will be judged by an expert jury and include proposals from artists, engravers, and the public. Designs will be anonymized until a final selection is made, with a preference for physical designs. The Secretary will encourage 3-dimensional designs for coin proposals, with a preference for physical designs. Compensation for the winning design will be at least $5,000, which will impact the sale price. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2018.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with sale prices at a discount. The coins issued under this Act will be sold at face value, surcharge, and design cost. Bulk sales will be discounted, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins issued under this Act include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half-dollar coin. Surcharges received by the Secretary are promptly paid to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation in New York for research purposes. The surcharge recipient is subject to audit requirements, and no surcharge may be included for the issuance of any coin under this Act. The Secretary may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to comply with the restriction under section 5112(m)(1) of title 31, United States Code.
